body: ['This live coverage has ended. For the latest updates, please go here.', 'In northern Gaza, the director of Indonesian Hospital said the facility was bombarded early Monday and that Israeli tanks had surrounded the hospital. Israel asserts that Hamas uses the hospitals as cover for its activities and infrastructure, which Hamas and doctors deny. At least 26 of the premature Palestinian babies who were at risk of dying after Gaza’s al-Shifa Hospital ran out of fuel for their incubators arrived in Egypt in an evacuation mission led by the World Health Organization.', '1/4', 'Follow World news', '']
['1/4', 'Follow World news', '']

['This live coverage has ended. For the latest updates, please go here. ', 'Eleven hostages were released by Hamas into Israel on Monday, according to the Israel Defense Forces. In exchange, 33 Palestinian civilians were set to be released from Israeli prison, a spokesman for Qatar’s Foreign Ministry said. Earlier Monday, Israel and Hamas agreed to a deal to extend the fragile pause in fighting in Gaza by two days, according to Qatari officials. Under the deal, mediated by Qatar and Egypt, additional women and children would be released from captivity in the Gaza Strip each day in exchange for Palestinian prisoners. Before Monday, Hamas released 58 hostages, including Thai and Philippine nationals, after a captive exchange deal between Israel and Hamas went into effect Friday. Israel has released more than 100 imprisoned Palestinian women and teenagers in exchange. While fighting has been paused, aid agencies have been racing to boost deliveries to Gaza.', '1/3', 'Follow World news', '']

['1/3', 'Follow World news', 'JERUSALEM — Since Friday, when the brief halt in Israel’s military campaign quieted the skies over Gaza for the first time since Oct. 7, trucks packed with flour, date bars and canned beans have trickled in through the Rafah crossing with Egypt. Vegetables, freshly harvested or retrieved from storage, reappeared on shelves. But the stomachs of Gazans of all classes are still rumbling. Parents go hungry to feed children who still need more. Food prices have soared. Fights have broken out in long aid lines. Begging is a new norm.', 'This is an excerpt from a full story.', 'National Security Council spokesman John Kirby said Thursday of Israeli military operations in Gaza following the pause that the United States does “not support a move to the south” unless Israel can account for the protection of civilians there.', 'Kirby added that “there’s a whole heck of a lot more innocent civilians in southern Gaza” because of corridors that Israel opened, pushing Gazans from the north to the south.', 'Israel refers to all Palestinian prisoners on its list for potential release as “terrorists,” with charges ranging from throwing stones to attempted murder.', 'The World Health Organization’s chief warned that “more people could die from disease than bombings” in Gaza because of poor living conditions and scarce health care. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus said Wednesday that overcrowding and a lack of food, water, medicines, sanitation and waste management were leading to higher cases of chickenpox, lice and diarrhea infections. He said a sustained cease-fire was “a matter of life or death for civilians.”', 'The Israel-Gaza war has gone on for months, and tensions have spilled into the surrounding Middle East region.', 'The war: On Oct. 7, Hamas militants launched an unprecedented cross-border attack on Israel, killing about 1,200 people and taking civilian hostages, including from a music festival. See photos and videos of how the deadly assault unfolded. Israel declared war on Hamas in response, launching a ground invasion that fueled the biggest displacement in the region since Israel’s creation in 1948. In July 2024, Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh was killed in an attack Hamas has blamed on Israel.', 'Gaza crisis: In the Gaza Strip, Israel has waged one of this century’s most destructive wars, killing tens of thousands and plunging at least half of the population into “famine-like conditions.” For months, Israel has resisted pressure from Western allies to allow more humanitarian aid into the enclave.', 'U.S. involvement: Despite tensions between Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and some U.S. politicians, including President Biden, the United States supports Israel with weapons, funds aid packages, and has vetoed or abstained from the United Nations’ cease-fire resolutions.', 'History: The roots of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and mistrust are deep and complex, predating the establishment of the state of Israel in 1948. Read more on the history of the Gaza Strip.', '']

['The seven-day pause in fighting between Israel and Hamas ended early Friday. Each side blamed the other. Israel said Hamas had “violated the operational pause and, in addition, fired toward Israeli territory,” while a Hamas official said talks to extend the pause were “thwarted by the Israelis” who had “refused” an offer to release elderly male hostages and the bodies of three Israeli hostages. The Washington Post could not immediately verify either claim. Several airstrikes were reported across Gaza on Friday morning; a Post photographer witnessed a strike 200 meters from a hospital in Khan Younis in the south. Sirens blared in Israeli communities near the Gaza border, the Israel Defense Forces said.', '1/4', 'Follow World news', 'Israel’s military is considering the establishment of a “buffer zone” inside Gaza once its war with Hamas is over to ensure that militants “cannot gather military capabilities close to the border and surprise Israel again,” an Israeli official said Friday.', 'Rep. Adam Smith (D-Wash.) said his home in Bellvue, Wash., was vandalized Thursday night by people advocating for a cease-fire in Gaza. A spokesman for the Bellvue Police said Friday the department was working with U.S. Capitol Police to investigate the incident that included graffiti spray painted on the home’s garage door.', 'This is an excerpt from a full story.', 'President Biden and the rest of his administration “will continue to remain deeply engaged” in trying to reinstate the pause in fighting in Gaza to enable “more hostages released and more aid getting in,” White House National Security Council spokesman John Kirby said Friday.', '“The onus is on Hamas” for the return to fighting, because it failed late Thursday to submit a list of the next group of  female and child hostages to be released, Kirby said.', 'The Israel-Gaza war has gone on for months, and tensions have spilled into the surrounding Middle East region.', 'The war: On Oct. 7, Hamas militants launched an unprecedented cross-border attack on Israel, killing about 1,200 people and taking civilian hostages, including from a music festival. See photos and videos of how the deadly assault unfolded. Israel declared war on Hamas in response, launching a ground invasion that fueled the biggest displacement in the region since Israel’s creation in 1948. In July 2024, Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh was killed in an attack Hamas has blamed on Israel.', 'Gaza crisis: In the Gaza Strip, Israel has waged one of this century’s most destructive wars, killing tens of thousands and plunging at least half of the population into “famine-like conditions.” For months, Israel has resisted pressure from Western allies to allow more humanitarian aid into the enclave.', 'U.S. involvement: Despite tensions between Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and some U.S. politicians, including President Biden, the United States supports Israel with weapons, funds aid packages, and has vetoed or abstained from the United Nations’ cease-fire resolutions.', 'History: The roots of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and mistrust are deep and complex, predating the establishment of the state of Israel in 1948. Read more on the history of the Gaza Strip.', '']
['1/3', 'Follow World news', '']
['This live coverage has ended. For the latest updates, please go here. ', '1/4', 'Follow World news', '']

['This live coverage has ended. For the latest updates, please go here.', 'Secretary of State Antony Blinken said there is a “gap” between Israel’s stated intent of protecting civilians and what’s happening in Gaza, an apparent crack in the administrations’ humanitarian agreement from last week. The Gaza Health Ministry said 350 people were killed in the enclave in 24 hours, bringing the total death toll to more than 17,000.', '1/7', 'Follow World news', '']

['The United States vetoed a U.N. Security Council draft resolution Friday that called for an immediate humanitarian cease-fire in Gaza. The resolution was backed by the majority of the U.N. Security Council. Earlier Friday, Israel said that it was continuing “intense close-quarter combat” in Khan Younis in southern Gaza as well as in the north of the enclave as its military operations show no sign of letting up.', '1/5', 'Follow World news', '']

['Israeli soldiers mistakenly shot dead three Israeli hostages — Yotam Haim and Alon Shamriz of Kibbutz Kfar Aza and Samer Al-Talalka of Kibbutz Nir Am — during fighting in Gaza, the Israel Defense Forces said Friday. IDF troops mistook the hostages, who had been captured in the Hamas-led attack on Israel on Oct. 7, for a threat and fired at them during fighting in the Shejaiya neighborhood east of Gaza City, the IDF said in a statement. Later, “a suspicion arose over the identities of the deceased,” so the bodies were transferred to Israel, where they were confirmed to be hostages. The deaths of the hostages sparked protests in Tel Aviv, according to reports in local media.', '1/7', 'Follow World news', '']

['This live coverage has ended. For the latest updates, please go here.', 'TEL AVIV — Protesters rallied while hostages’ families planned to meet with Israeli cabinet members Saturday, frustrated that the government has not taken a new path beyond a military operation to secure the release of their loved ones who were taken Oct. 7. Earlier in the day a senior Israeli military official said three hostages killed by Israeli forces in Gaza were carrying a makeshift white flag when a soldier felt threatened and opened fire, violating “our rules of engagement.”', '1/5', 'Follow World news', '']

['This live coverage has ended. For the latest updates, please go here.', 'Yemen-based Houthi militants said Tuesday they would not stop their “military operations” in the Red Sea after U.S. Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin announced the formation of a multinational naval coalition to protect commercial ships in the region. The Iranian-aligned group has targeted vessels with ties to Israel or traveling there. Meanwhile, talks have resumed on a potential deal to free more than 100 hostages still held by Hamas.', '1/5', 'Follow World news', 'The Israel-Gaza war has gone on for months, and tensions have spilled into the surrounding Middle East region.', 'The war: On Oct. 7, Hamas militants launched an unprecedented cross-border attack on Israel, killing about 1,200 people and taking civilian hostages, including from a music festival. See photos and videos of how the deadly assault unfolded. Israel declared war on Hamas in response, launching a ground invasion that fueled the biggest displacement in the region since Israel’s creation in 1948. In July 2024, Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh was killed in an attack Hamas has blamed on Israel.', 'Gaza crisis: In the Gaza Strip, Israel has waged one of this century’s most destructive wars, killing tens of thousands and plunging at least half of the population into “famine-like conditions.” For months, Israel has resisted pressure from Western allies to allow more humanitarian aid into the enclave.', 'U.S. involvement: Despite tensions between Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and some U.S. politicians, including President Biden, the United States supports Israel with weapons, funds aid packages, and has vetoed or abstained from the United Nations’ cease-fire resolutions.', 'History: The roots of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and mistrust are deep and complex, predating the establishment of the state of Israel in 1948. Read more on the history of the Gaza Strip.', '']

['This live coverage has now ended. For the latest updates, please go here.', 'At least 70 people were killed late Sunday in central Gaza when an Israeli airstrike hit a residential block in the Maghazi refugee camp, according to the Gaza Health Ministry. The Israeli military said Sunday that 15 soldiers had been killed in Gaza over the weekend, with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu vowing to press on with the war.', '1/4', 'Follow World news', '']

['This live coverage has ended. For the latest updates, please go here.', 'Sen. Tim Kaine (D-Va.) criticized the State Department’s circumvention of Congress in approving a $147.5 million arms sale to Israel. Kaine, a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, demanded a “public explanation of the rationale behind this decision — the second such decision this month.” In a Friday announcement, the State Department said the proposed sale of 155-millimeter artillery shells and related equipment is consistent with the U.S. commitment to Israel’s security and efforts to help it “develop and maintain a strong and ready self-defense capability.”', '1/4', 'Follow World news', 'South Africa  has instituted proceedings against Israel at the International Court of Justice, calling on the Court to find that in its war in Gaza, Israel has violated the Genocide Convention of 1948, which codified genocide as an international crime.', 'In its filing on Friday, South Africa said Israel had “engaged in, is engaging in and risks further engaging in genocidal acts against the Palestinian people in Gaza,” according to a statement published by the Court. The International Court of Justice, an organ of the United Nations, was instituted to resolve legal disputes between U.N. member states.', 'Israel’s Foreign Ministry denounced the filing on social media Friday, and called on the Court to dismiss the filing.', '“Israel rejects with disgust the blood libel spread by South Africa in its application to the International Court of Justice,” said Lior Haiat, spokesman for Israel’s Foreign Ministry, on the social media platform X. “Israel is committed to international law and acts in accordance with it, and directs its military efforts solely against the Hamas terrorist organization and the other terrorist organizations cooperating with Hamas.”', '“Israel has made it clear that the residents of the Gaza Strip are not the enemy, and is making every effort to limit harm to civilians and to facilitate the entry of humanitarian aid to the Gaza Strip,” Haiat added.', 'The Palestinian Foreign Ministry, based in the West Bank, welcomed the South African action, saying in a statement that “Israel’s stated policy, acts and omissions are genocidal in character.”', '“Urgent intervention and action is needed to protect against and prevent further harm to the Palestinian people,” the ministry continued.', 'The Israel-Gaza war has gone on for months, and tensions have spilled into the surrounding Middle East region.', 'The war: On Oct. 7, Hamas militants launched an unprecedented cross-border attack on Israel, killing about 1,200 people and taking civilian hostages, including from a music festival. See photos and videos of how the deadly assault unfolded. Israel declared war on Hamas in response, launching a ground invasion that fueled the biggest displacement in the region since Israel’s creation in 1948. In July 2024, Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh was killed in an attack Hamas has blamed on Israel.', 'Gaza crisis: In the Gaza Strip, Israel has waged one of this century’s most destructive wars, killing tens of thousands and plunging at least half of the population into “famine-like conditions.” For months, Israel has resisted pressure from Western allies to allow more humanitarian aid into the enclave.', 'U.S. involvement: Despite tensions between Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and some U.S. politicians, including President Biden, the United States supports Israel with weapons, funds aid packages, and has vetoed or abstained from the United Nations’ cease-fire resolutions.', 'History: The roots of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and mistrust are deep and complex, predating the establishment of the state of Israel in 1948. Read more on the history of the Gaza Strip.', '']

['Get the latest news on the 2024 presidential election from our reporters in Washington and on the campaign trail.', '1/4', 'Follow Election 2024', 'Donald Trump said the economy is in danger of crashing and he hopes it happens within the next year, before he would return to office if he wins the election in November.', '“We have an economy that’s so fragile, and the only reason it’s running now is it’s running off the fumes of what we did,” Trump said in an interview with right-wing host Lou Dobbs that aired tonight. “And when there’s a crash, I hope it’s going to be during this next 12 months because I don’t want to be Herbert Hoover,” Trump added, referring to the president during the 1929 stock market crash that led to the Great Depression.', 'President Biden has begun the 2024 election year with a concerted effort to train the nation’s eyes on his presumptive opponent, Donald Trump.', 'Biden delivered a speech Friday marking the third anniversary of the Jan. 6, 2021, insurrection and pitching Trump as a threat to democracy. On Monday, he spoke at the historically Black church in South Carolina that was the site of a racist massacre and accused Trump’s MAGA Republicans of trying to erase history.', 'This is an excerpt from a full story.', 'Former president Donald Trump and former Fox Business host Lou Dobbs are going heavy on baseless stolen election claims in an interview airing on Dobbs’s new show on the pro-Trump John Fredericks Radio Network. “I think we’re very close to being at the end of our country as we know it,” Trump said.', 'Across party lines and even within the two major parties, there is disagreement about whether the early months of this year will have a significant impact on the fall election. One view holds that nothing other than a major surprise early this year will reshape a Biden-versus-Trump contest.', 'Nikki Haley has been pressed on several of Donald Trump’s attacks on her at this Fox News town hall. Asked about Trump criticizing her for previously saying she wouldn’t run against him, she cites three changes since her comment: Afghanistan, inflation and “ridiculous” midterm loses.', '“I appreciate all the attention President Trump is giving me. It is quite sweet and thoughtful of him,” she said.', 'Follow live updates on the 2024 election and the contest between Vice President Kamala Harris and former president Donald Trump from our reporters on the campaign trail and in Washington.', 'Potential assassination attempt: Trump was unharmed in what authorities are investigating as another potential assassination attempt, after a man pointed a rifle into a Florida golf course where the former president was playing. Police arrested Ryan Wesley Routh, a 58-year-old man who spent recent years trying to join the war in Ukraine, according to online posts and law enforcement officials.', 'Policy positions: We’ve collected Harris’s and Trump’s stances on the most important issues — abortion, economic policy, immigration and more.', 'Presidential polls: Check out how Harris and Trump stack up, according to The Washington Post’s presidential polling averages of seven battleground states. We’ve identified eight possible paths to victory based on the candidates’ current standing in the polls.', 'Senate control: Senate Democrats are at risk of losing their slim 51-49 majority this fall. The Post breaks down the eight races and three long shots that could determine Senate control.', '']

['This live coverage has ended. For the latest updates, please go here. ', 'U.S. and British military forces, with support from Australia, Bahrain, Canada and the Netherlands, struck “a number of targets in Yemen used by Houthi rebels to endanger freedom of navigation in one of the world’s most vital waterways,” President Biden said late Thursday. The Houthi-run Masirah news channel said airstrikes had targeted a military air base adjacent to the international airport in Sanaa, the Yemeni capital, where residents reported the sound of explosions around 2:30 a.m.', '1/4', 'Follow World news', '']

['This live coverage has ended. For the latest updates, please go here.', 'The United States continued its assault on Houthi militants in Yemen, carrying out a strike on a Houthi radar site early Saturday local time, U.S. Central Command said. The latest strike caused no injuries or damage, a Houthi official told Al Jazeera on Saturday, vowing a “firm, strong and effective response.” In Gaza, Israeli strikes killed dozens more people as an internet blackout continued into a second day Saturday, according to monitoring group NetBlocks. Sunday will mark 100 days of war between Israel and Hamas.', '1/6', 'Follow World news', '']

['This live coverage has ended. For the latest updates, please go here.', 'Israel’s defense minister said Monday that its high-intensity operation in the northern end of the Gaza Strip had ended, a change U.S. officials had urged the Israeli military to adopt by February. In northern Iraq’s semiautonomous Kurdish region, Iran’s Revolutionary Guard Corps said they attacked what they said was an “espionage” site of Israel’s Mossad intelligence agency early Tuesday local time, according to state media.', '1/6', 'Follow World news', '']

['Former president Donald Trump is back in New Hampshire on Friday evening for rallies leading up to the Republican primary on Tuesday. Former U.N. ambassador Nikki Haley, who is seeking to stall Trump’s momentum with a strong showing in the Granite State, is out on the campaign trail, and Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis (R) is also in the state on Friday.', '1/3', 'Follow Election 2024', '']

['U.S. naval forces launched three additional strikes against Houthi forces in Yemen on Friday morning, targeting anti-ship missiles, according to National Security Council spokesman John Kirby. He described the attacks as “preemptive” and in self-defense. The strikes, which followed successive rounds over the past 10 days, came after Houthi militants targeted a U.S. tanker, in the third such attack on commercial shipping in three days, U.S. Central Command said. President Biden acknowledged that U.S. strikes have not deterred the Iran-aligned group. In the Gaza Strip, internet and cellphone communications were gradually restored Friday night, ending a week-long outage that kept most of the territory’s 2.1 million people cut off, amid a war and humanitarian crisis.', '1/6', 'Follow World news', '']
['1/4', 'Follow World news', '']

['The United States conducted strikes in Iraq and Syria on Friday, beginning what the Biden administration said will be a multiday retaliatory campaign against Iranian-aligned militants whom the White House blames for the killing of three U.S. soldiers in Jordan on Sunday.', '“Our response began today,” President Biden said in a statement following the strikes. “It will continue at times and places of our choosing.” He said the United States “does not seek conflict in the Middle East” but cautioned that attacks against Americans would garner a response.', '1/4', 'Follow World news', '']
['1/5', 'Follow World news', '']

['Israel’s military said it rescued two hostages from the southern Gazan city of Rafah early Monday while carrying out a wave of strikes, which Gaza’s Health Ministry said killed at least 67 people. As Gazans reported violent bombardment from all directions in Rafah, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said he would use “continued military pressure” to return the remaining hostages.', '1/7', 'Follow World news', '']
['Get the latest news on the 2024 election from our reporters on the campaign trail and in Washington.', '1/4', 'Follow Election 2024', '']

['Israel launched an attack on neighboring Lebanon on Wednesday, striking various locations in the south that killed at least four people and raising the specter of war between the two countries. The strikes followed a morning attack launched from Lebanon into Israel that struck a house and a military base. One Israeli woman was killed, and at least eight people were injured, according to a government spokeswoman. Meanwhile, negotiations over a potential deal to pause the fighting in Gaza and release the remaining hostages continued into a second day— though appeared to falter —on Wednesday, amid mounting concerns over an expected Israeli military operation in the crowded southern city of Rafah.', '1/4', 'Follow World news', '']

['The Israeli military continued its raid on Nasser Hospital, the main hospital in southern Gaza’s Khan Younis, on Friday, calling it an operation to recover the bodies of hostages. The Gaza Health Ministry said five intensive care patients have died of a lack of oxygen during a power outage at the hospital and that the military was moving patients and entering buildings in the complex.', '1/5', 'Follow World news', '']

['The United States vetoed an Arab-sponsored resolution that called for an immediate cease-fire in Gaza and the release of all hostages in a U.N. Security Council vote Tuesday. The United States has circulated its own draft resolution seeking a six-week pause in fighting — calling it a “temporary ceasefire” — and the phased release of hostages.', '1/6', 'Follow World news', '']

['Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu released a postwar plan for Gaza that pushes for indefinite military control over the Palestinian enclave. In Paris, negotiators are trying to reach a deal for the release of hostages and a cessation of fighting in Gaza. An Israeli official said Israel’s delegation headed to Paris on Friday for the talks, which are expected to include senior U.S., Qatari and Egyptian officials.', '1/6', 'Follow World news', '']

['A man is in critical condition after setting himself on fire while wearing military fatigues midday Sunday outside the Israeli Embassy in D.C., authorities said.', 'No one else was injured in the incident, which took place just before 1 p.m. in the 3500 block of International Drive NW. A video shared online that multiple officials said appeared to be posted by the man shows him referring to  his service in the U.S. armed forces and shouting “Free Palestine” as he burned.', '']

['President Biden and former president Donald Trump are making dueling visits to different areas along the U.S.-Mexico border Thursday, underscoring how central immigration issues are in this year’s presidential election campaign. Biden, during a trip to Brownsville, Tex., chided Republicans for blocking a Senate bill that would have provided billions of dollars in additional funding for border security. Trump, during a visit to Eagle Pass, Tex., blamed Biden for illegal crossings.', '1/2', 'Follow Election 2024', '']

['Officials from the United States, Europe and United Arab Emirates have announced plans for a new maritime corridor to deliver much-needed humanitarian aid to the Gaza Strip by sea. European Commission head Ursula von der Leyen said a pilot aid delivery operation would begin Friday, with hopes the corridor could formally open this weekend. In his State of the Union speech Thursday, President Biden unveiled a plan to build a temporary pier on Gaza’s coast to scale up aid shipments.', '1/5', 'Follow World news', '']
['1/4', 'Follow World news', '']

['A dire food shortage and ongoing Israeli strikes in Gaza have made for a somber start to Ramadan — normally a time of dawn-to-dusk fasting and celebration — after failure to agree on a cease-fire by the start of the Muslim holy month. A ship loaded with desperately needed humanitarian aid has departed Cyprus for Gaza, as part of a maritime aid corridor announced by the United States and its allies last week.', '1/4', 'Follow World news', '']

['President Biden returned to the campaign trail Wednesday — with a trip to the battleground state of Wisconsin — after he and former president Donald Trump secured their parties’ nominations for the presidency Tuesday night. Their victories in the latest nominating contests set up a rematch that has appeared inevitable for months.', '1/4', 'Follow Election 2024', 'MILWAUKEE — President Biden, speaking Wednesday in a community that he cited as a painful example of racist urban policy, highlighted a new economic strategy aimed at revitalizing places that for decades have been cut off from the nation’s growing prosperity.', 'This is an excerpt from a full story.', 'Donald Trump set off a panic in some of the more extreme corners of his base last week during President Biden’s State of the Union. Trump’s offense? Taking credit for the coronavirus vaccines that Biden hailed.', 'Alex Jones threatened to go on the “warpath” if Trump kept it up. Michael Flynn agreed with Jones’s plea for Trump to stop. And Charlie Kirk chimed in among his fellow right-wing influencers with a warning of electoral peril for Trump.', 'This is an excerpt from a full story.', 'Independent presidential candidate Robert F. Kennedy Jr., who said he has selected a running mate and will announce the person in California later this month, had a conversation with NFL player Aaron Rodgers about the role, according to someone familiar with the process. Though Kennedy’s campaign confirmed to the New York Times that Rodgers was high on his list, alongside former independent Minnesota governor Jesse Ventura, it has not said if Rodgers was offered the job.', 'This is an excerpt from a full story.', 'Follow live updates on the 2024 election and the contest between Vice President Kamala Harris and former president Donald Trump from our reporters on the campaign trail and in Washington.', 'Potential assassination attempt: Trump was unharmed in what authorities are investigating as another potential assassination attempt, after a man pointed a rifle into a Florida golf course where the former president was playing. Police arrested Ryan Wesley Routh, a 58-year-old man who spent recent years trying to join the war in Ukraine, according to online posts and law enforcement officials.', 'Policy positions: We’ve collected Harris’s and Trump’s stances on the most important issues — abortion, economic policy, immigration and more.', 'Presidential polls: Check out how Harris and Trump stack up, according to The Washington Post’s presidential polling averages of seven battleground states. We’ve identified eight possible paths to victory based on the candidates’ current standing in the polls.', 'Senate control: Senate Democrats are at risk of losing their slim 51-49 majority this fall. The Post breaks down the eight races and three long shots that could determine Senate control.', '']

['President Biden is continuing his ramped-up campaign travel following last week’s State of the Union address. On Thursday, he visited Saginaw, Mich., for a campaign event in another battleground state. In last month’s Michigan Democratic primary, more than 100,000 voters cast ballots for “uncommitted” instead of Biden, part of an effort to protest the president’s handling of the Israel-Gaza war.', '1/4', 'Follow Election 2024', 'One week ago, President Biden gave his State of the Union address. It was well-received; his forceful arguments — many ad-libbed — were an effective way to rebut (though certainly not completely dispel) even good-faith concerns that he is frail physically or mentally. Polling conducted among those who watched the speech (18 percent more people than in 2023) determined that the response was largely positive.', 'This is an excerpt from a full story.', 'SAN ANTONIO — Rep. Matt Gaetz (R-Fla.) visited Texas on Thursday to campaign for a primary challenger to a House GOP colleague, boasting that he was skipping the conference’s annual retreat to wade into the intraparty battle.', '“Some of my Republican colleagues are a little upset with me today,” Gaetz said, acknowledging that the retreat was underway in West Virginia. “Pardon me for saying so, but doesn’t it sort of feel like congressional Republicans have been in a state of constant retreat?”', 'Former president Donald Trump leads President Biden by five percentage points in a five-way contest in Michigan, a critical presidential battleground state, according to a new poll.', 'A senior aide to Donald Trump will have to go to prison while he appeals his conviction for refusing to testify before Congress about his involvement in efforts to undo the results of the 2020 election.', 'Peter Navarro, a 74-year-old economist, “has not shown that his appeal presents substantial questions of law or fact likely to result” undoing the conviction or his four-month sentence, a unanimous panel of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit ruled Thursday.', 'This is an excerpt from a full story.', 'President Biden issued a statement on Thursday mourning the death of Nex Benedict, a nonbinary teen who collapsed a day after an altercation at a high school in Owasso, Okla.', 'Follow live updates on the 2024 election and the contest between Vice President Kamala Harris and former president Donald Trump from our reporters on the campaign trail and in Washington.', 'Potential assassination attempt: Trump was unharmed in what authorities are investigating as another potential assassination attempt, after a man pointed a rifle into a Florida golf course where the former president was playing. Police arrested Ryan Wesley Routh, a 58-year-old man who spent recent years trying to join the war in Ukraine, according to online posts and law enforcement officials.', 'Policy positions: We’ve collected Harris’s and Trump’s stances on the most important issues — abortion, economic policy, immigration and more.', 'Presidential polls: Check out how Harris and Trump stack up, according to The Washington Post’s presidential polling averages of seven battleground states. We’ve identified eight possible paths to victory based on the candidates’ current standing in the polls.', 'Senate control: Senate Democrats are at risk of losing their slim 51-49 majority this fall. The Post breaks down the eight races and three long shots that could determine Senate control.', '']

['Secretary of State Antony Blinken on Thursday visited Egypt, where he met with President Abdel Fatah El-Sisi as part of his regional trip for talks to halt the fighting in Gaza. Blinken is set to visit Israel on Friday, as negotiations for a cease-fire and hostage release deal in Doha, Qatar, appear to falter. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu approved a delegation of Israeli officials led by David Barnea, head of Israel’s Mossad intelligence service, to travel to Qatar on Friday to work on the cease-fire negotiations, Netanyahu’s office said.', '1/5', 'Follow World news', '']

['President Biden appeared at a campaign finance meeting in New York on Friday before heading to Camp David in Maryland for the weekend. On Thursday night, Biden appeared at a star-studded fundraiser in New York that included two former presidents — Bill Clinton and Barack Obama — and an array of entertainers.', '1/4', 'Follow Election 2024', '']

['Former president Donald Trump returned to the campaign trail on Tuesday, with events in two Midwestern battleground states: Michigan and Wisconsin. President Biden is in Washington with no public events scheduled.', '1/3', 'Follow Election 2024', 'It’s difficult to think of a more combustible mixture than Donald Trump and a gag order. Even with Trump’s freedom on the line, that combination is smoldering again.', 'This is an excerpt from a full story.', 'A prominent ally of Donald Trump is pressing Nebraska officials to change the way the state awards electoral votes.', 'Nebraska is one of two states that does not have a winner-take-all policy, where the winner of the statewide vote receives all the state’s electoral votes. Nebraska’s electoral votes are instead split among the statewide and congressional district winners, including a swing district in the Omaha area that President Biden carried in 2020 as Trump easily won statewide.', 'Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.), who in February said he will step down as leader of the chamber’s GOP conference in November, said he plans on finishing his Senate term, which ends in 2026.', 'McConnell’s decision to step down from leadership raised questions of whether he would finish his seventh term. He’s been in the Senate since 1985, making him the longest-serving senator in Kentucky’s history.', 'GRAND RAPIDS, Mich. — Donald Trump doubled down in a campaign speech on immigration on referring to some undocumented immigrants as “animals.” He made headlines last month for declaring at a rally that some are “not people” — and in remarks Tuesday, said Georgia nursing student Laken Riley was “murdered by an illegal alien animal.”', 'Speaking in Michigan, Donald Trump gave a shout-out to Tom Homan, who served as his head of Immigration and Customs Enforcement. Trump is attending a gala fundraiser at Mar-a-Lago on Thursday for a nonprofit that Homan leads called Border911.', 'Follow live updates on the 2024 election and the contest between Vice President Kamala Harris and former president Donald Trump from our reporters on the campaign trail and in Washington.', 'Potential assassination attempt: Trump was unharmed in what authorities are investigating as another potential assassination attempt, after a man pointed a rifle into a Florida golf course where the former president was playing. Police arrested Ryan Wesley Routh, a 58-year-old man who spent recent years trying to join the war in Ukraine, according to online posts and law enforcement officials.', 'Policy positions: We’ve collected Harris’s and Trump’s stances on the most important issues — abortion, economic policy, immigration and more.', 'Presidential polls: Check out how Harris and Trump stack up, according to The Washington Post’s presidential polling averages of seven battleground states. We’ve identified eight possible paths to victory based on the candidates’ current standing in the polls.', 'Senate control: Senate Democrats are at risk of losing their slim 51-49 majority this fall. The Post breaks down the eight races and three long shots that could determine Senate control.', '']

['Vice President Harris gave a campaign speech on abortion on Friday, three days after the Arizona Supreme Court ruled that an 1864 law forbidding almost all abortions is operative in the swing state. ['President Biden welcomed two foreign leaders to the White House on Monday — Iraqi Prime Minister Mohammed Shia al-Sudani, followed by Czech Prime Minister Petr Fiala — while jury selection got underway in former president Donald Trump’s first criminal trial, in New York.', '1/4', 'Follow Election 2024', 'NEW YORK — The opening day of Donald Trump’s criminal trial delved deeply into his tabloid-fueled sex life, as lawyers and the judge debated how many salacious details jurors should eventually hear as they decide whether he broke the law to cover up hush money payments.', 'This is an excerpt from a full story.', 'Over the weekend, the New York Times released the latest in its series of national polls conducted by Siena College. ['Israel’s war cabinet met for a second day to weigh a response to Iran’s missile and drone attack over the weekend, as the Biden administration said the U.S. would not take part in any reprisal attacks. World leaders condemned Iran’s barrage and called for restraint. During a visit to Nevatim air base, which was damaged in the Iranian barrage, Israel Defense Forces Chief of Staff Herzi Halevi said in remarks shared on social media that Israel would respond to the attack, but did not say how.', '1/7', 'Follow World news', '']

['President Biden appeared Friday at a conference in Washington hosted by the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, a labor union that last year endorsed his 2024 reelection. It’s the latest attempt by Biden to bolster his support among blue-collar voters who will be key in several battleground states in November.', '1/3', 'Follow Election 2024', '']

['The House approved a $95 billion package of foreign aid bills that would provide funding for Ukraine, Israel and Taiwan, among other priorities. The bills moved forward despite a far-right threat to oust House Speaker Mike Johnson (R-La.) if he advanced Ukraine aid.', '1/4', 'Follow Politics', '']

['Israeli officials and American lawmakers celebrated the U.S. Senate voting overwhelmingly to advance a package of bills that would give billions in aid to Israel, as well as Ukraine and Taiwan. Meanwhile, antiwar demonstrations at university campuses across the United States continue to escalate — with over 150 students and faculty arrested so far.', '1/6', 'Follow World news', '']

['A delegation from Egypt traveled to Israel on Friday in a bid to avert a planned Israeli offensive in Rafah, where much of Gaza’s population has been displaced, according to an Israeli official who spoke on the condition of anonymity due to the matter’s sensitivity. The trip, which follows an Israeli war cabinet meeting Thursday to discuss hostage deal negotiations, signals a resumption of efforts to broker a deal after months of failed talks. National security adviser Jake Sullivan told MSNBC on Friday that there was “new momentum, new life,” to the hostage and cease-fire talks.', '1/6', 'Follow World news', '']

['This live coverage has ended. For the latest updates, please go here. | Dozens of New York police officers in riot gear entered Columbia University’s campus Tuesday night after issuing a dispersal order to protesters gathered outside one of the school’s entrances. Officers breached a building occupied by protesters and removed students from the campus with their hands zip-tied behind their backs. A police spokesman said multiple people had been arrested. Pro-Palestinian demonstrators have demanded for weeks that universities divest from Israeli-linked companies more than six months into Israel’s war with Hamas.', '1/5', 'Subscribe to comment and get the full experience. Choose your plan →', '']

['Confrontations between pro-Palestinian protesters and police are continuing on campuses across the United States, a day after New York police breached a Columbia University building occupied by demonstrators and arrested about 300 people at Columbia and the City College of New York. Police arrested 15 protesters at Fordham University and 34 at the University of Wisconsin in Madison. In Los Angeles, UCLA’s chancellor denounced “instigators” whom he blamed for violence that broke out overnight Tuesday between pro-Palestinian demonstrators and counterprotesters who tried to dismantle their camp.', '1/4', '']

['The New York Police Department began clearing encampments at New York University and the New School on Friday morning and took more than 50 demonstrators into custody. Pro-Palestinian protests and resulting police actions continued to roil the campus and many others across the country; more than 130 people were arrested at the State University of New York at New Paltz, and 17 were taken into custody at the University of Notre Dame late Thursday night. In Oregon, law enforcement officers cleared a library at Portland State University for a second time Thursday night, with the day’s arrests there reaching at least 30.', '1/5', '']

['New York Supreme Court Justice Juan Merchan  ruled Monday that Donald Trump again violated his gag order in the New York hush money trial, and he warned that he would consider jailing the former president if the violations continue. After the ruling, testimony included retired Trump Organization comptroller Jeffrey McConney talking about business records and practices that are at the heart of the case. Merchan sent the jury home for the day shortly after 4 p.m.', '1/3', 'Follow Politics', 'Trump spoke to reporters shortly before he left the courthouse, calling Justice Juan Merchan a “disaster” and addressing being held in contempt Monday morning for violating his gag order.', '“This judge has given me a gag order and said, ‘You’ll go to jail if you violate it,’” Trump told reporters. “Frankly our Constitution is much more important than jail. I’ll do that sacrifice any day.”', 'Trump also complained about the trial’s timeline.', '“We just found out the government just said they want two to three more weeks,” he said. “That means they want to keep me off the trail.” Trump has a rally scheduled this weekend in New Jersey.', 'Donald Trump has left the courtroom for the day.', 'After the jury was dismissed, Justice Juan Merchan asked the prosecutors for an updated trial schedule. Assistant District Attorney Joshua Steinglass estimated that the government’s case will last two more weeks: This week, next week and the first day or two of the following week.', 'Donald Trump and his lawyers have entered the courtroom after the lunch break.', 'Prosecutors have reentered the courtroom after the lunch break.', 'Jeffrey McConney, a former executive at the Trump Organization, testified Monday during cross-examination that he did not have information about Donald Trump dictating how finance professionals should document a $130,000 reimbursement payment to his then-lawyer, Michael Cohen.', 'As he leaves the courtroom for the lunch break, Trump gives a thumbs up to reporters. He appeared to have been paying close attention to Jeffrey McConney’s testimony.', 'Cross-examination of Jeffrey McConney is done; prosecutor Matthew Colangelo did some redirect. On his way out of the room, McConney nodded at his former boss seated at the defense table and Donald Trump appeared to say hello back by pumping his fist in McConney’s direction. This was McConney’s third time in two years testifying in a Trump-related case in New York state courts.', 'Jeffrey McConney, a longtime accountant for the Trump Organization, has twice subtly suggested on the witness stand that he did not think Michael Cohen was much of a lawyer.', 'At the start of his cross-examination, Trump lawyer Emil Bove asked him: “Michael Cohen was a lawyer, correct?” McConney replied: “Okay,” causing laughter in the courtroom.', 'Earlier Monday, when prosecutors asked McConney about Cohen, he said tartly: “He said he was a lawyer.”', '']

['The World Health Organization said Wednesday that the closure of the Rafah border crossing meant health services in southern Gaza would run out of fuel in three days. “Without more aid flowing into Gaza, we cannot sustain our lifesaving support to hospitals,” WHO Director General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus said at a briefing. President Biden told CNN Wednesday that he would halt the shipment of U.S. offensive weapons to Israel if the country moves ahead with a long-planned ground invasion of Rafah.', '1/7', 'Follow World news', '']

['Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Thursday that Israel was strong enough to fight alone as the United States warned that it could cut military aid to the country. “If we have to stand alone, we will stand alone,” Netanyahu said in a video message Thursday for Israel’s Independence Day. Rear Adm. Daniel Hagari, the IDF’s spokesman, added Thursday that the IDF had the “necessary weapons” for its planned operations, “including in Rafah.” Their remarks came after President Biden threatened to halt shipment of U.S. offensive weapons to Israel if the country moves ahead with its long-planned ground invasion of Rafah in the Gaza Strip.', '1/6', 'Follow World news', '']

['Israeli forces are advancing on the southern city of Rafah, aiming to destroy what Israeli officials have called the last significant Hamas stronghold in Gaza, at the same time that Israel and the militant group are again clashing in areas in the north. The Gaza Health Ministry said Monday that the health system in the strip will collapse within “a few hours” due to a lack of fuel needed to power generators and ambulances, after similar warnings from aid agencies last week.', '1/7', 'Follow World news', '']

['The United Nations said its staff member Waibhav Anil Kale, 46, was killed in Rafah on Monday in an attack on a U.N. vehicle. The shots that killed the worker “came from a tank in the area,” a spokesman for the U.N. Secretary General said later Tuesday, noting that only Israel operates tanks in Gaza. The car was marked with a U.N. flag, and Israeli authorities had been informed of its movements, a different U.N. spokesman told reporters earlier in the day. The Israel Defense Forces said Monday that they had not been made aware of the route of the vehicle, adding that the incident was “under review.”', '1/8', 'Follow World news', '']

['This live coverage has ended. For the latest news, please go here. ', 'There were no signs of life at the crash site of a helicopter that had been carrying Iranian President Ebrahim Raisi in the country’s mountainous northwest, according to state-run media, which said Iranian Foreign Minister Hossein Amir-Abdollahian and other officials were also on board. Early Monday, more than 12 hours after the crash was reported, rescue teams located the chopper, Iran’s Red Crescent Society told state-run Islamic Republic News Agency.', '1/4', 'Follow World news', 'Subscribe to comment and get the full experience. Choose your plan →', '']

['Iranian President Ebrahim Raisi died in a helicopter crash in the country’s East Azerbaijan province, along with Foreign Minister Hossein Amir-Abdollahian and other officials, Iranian state media reported. First Vice President Mohammad Mokhber was named Monday as interim president. Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, asked Mokhber to ensure the election of a new president within 50 days, state media reported.', '1/5', 'Follow World news', 'The helicopter that crashed while carrying the Iranian president through mountainous fog was a U.S.-designed Bell 212, according to state media and photographs verified by The Washington Post.', 'The Bell 212 aircraft is a widely used civilian version of the Vietnam-era Huey military helicopter, operated by armed forces and businesses around the globe. The model is a two-blade twin-engine medium helicopter with up to 15 seats that first flew in 1968, according to Skybrary, an aviation database.', 'Ali Bagheri Kani, a deputy foreign minister and nuclear negotiator for Iran, has been named the country’s acting foreign minister, state media said. Kani succeeds Hossein Amir-Abdollahian, a career diplomat, who died in the helicopter crash. It’s unclear whether Kani will retain his new post after an election is held within 50 days and a new government takes control.', 'National Security Council spokesman John Kirby defended the Biden administration’s decision to offer condolences on Iranian President Ebrahim Raisi’s death, calling it a “typical practice” to acknowledge the death of a foreign leader.', 'At the same time, Kirby said Raisi was responsible for “atrocious” human rights violations and blamed him for Iran’s support of proxy groups in the Middle East, including Hamas, “which obviously led to the slaughter of 1,200 innocent Israeli people.”', '“The United States had no part to play” in the crash that killed Iranian President Ebrahim Raisi and other Iranian officials, Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin said at a news conference Monday.', 'Around the same time, the United States expressed official condolences for the deaths of Raisi, Iranian Foreign Minister Hossein Amir-Abdollahian and others in the helicopter, in a statement from State Department spokesman Matthew Miller.', 'The death of Iranian President Ebrahim Raisi elicited shocked responses from several world leaders and political figures, many of whom have aligned themselves with the country on issues such as the war in Gaza or through a mutual resistance to Western powers.', 'Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro offered his condolences on social media, calling Raisi an “exemplary person” and an “extraordinary world leader.”', '']

['Rep. Andy Kim is projected to win the Democratic primary for Senate in New Jersey, according to the Associated Press. The seat is held by embattled Sen. Bob Menendez (D-N.J.), who on Monday filed to run for reelection as an independent amid his trial on federal corruption charges. Menendez’s son, Rep. Rob Menendez (D-N.J.), was also projected to survive a primary challenge in a race that was largely overshadowed by his father’s legal issues. Former president Donald Trump faced Republican primary voters for the first time as a felon Tuesday as voters went to the polls in Montana, New Jersey, New Mexico and South Dakota. Voters in Iowa and D.C. also selected nominees in down-ballot races. Trump was convicted last week by a New York jury on 34 counts of falsifying business records to conceal a hush money payment to an adult-film actress.', '1/3', 'Follow Election 2024', '']

['Secretary of State Antony Blinken said Israel should not reoccupy the Gaza Strip, after Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu vowed that Israel would assume responsibility for Gaza’s security “for an indefinite period.” Blinken told reporters that “Gaza cannot continue to be run by Hamas” but that “it’s also clear that Israel cannot occupy Gaza.” In remarks Wednesday, Israeli government spokesman Eylon Levy said that how Gaza would be controlled after the conflict remained uncertain but that Hamas would not play a role. In response to calls for a cease-fire, Levy said the war would “continue at full force” until Hamas’s “military and governing machine” had been destroyed.', '1/4', 'Follow World news', 'Here are the biggest news items from the Israel-Gaza war on Nov. 8.', 'Israel’s military said in a news release Wednesday that it had destroyed 130 tunnel shafts since the start of the war in the Gaza Strip. The Washington Post could not independently verify the claim. Hamas militants maintain a complex network of tunnels in Gaza. Stores of water and oxygen found in the tunnels indicate plans for prolonged stays, according to the Israel Defense Forces statement.', 'A group of Senate Democrats sent a letter to President Biden pushing him for details about Israel’s plans for the future and whether the country is taking measures to protect civilians in Gaza, among other requests.', 'After the war, Gaza “must be demilitarized,” but little is certain beyond that, Eylon Levy, a spokesman for Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, told reporters Wednesday. Benny Gantz, Netanyahu’s political rival who joined his wartime cabinet as part of a unity government, said at a news briefing that he did now know how Gaza would be governed after the conflict, but that Hamas would not play a role. ', 'Peace in Gaza will require “Palestinian-led governance and Gaza unified with the West Bank under the Palestinian Authority,” Secretary of State Antony Blinken told reporters in Tokyo, after meeting with European, Canadian and Japanese foreign ministers Wednesday.', 'Blinken’s statements offer the fullest vision to date of the Biden administration’s view on ensuring stability and safety in Gaza after the war.', 'The Rafah border crossing from Gaza into Egypt was closed Wednesday, according to State Department spokesman Vedant Patel.', '“Our understanding is that given a security circumstance, the Rafah border crossing remains closed today,” Patel said at a briefing at the State Department on Wednesday. The crossing is also the only route out of the Gaza Strip that has remained open since Hamas’s Oct. 7 attack on Israel.', 'The Israel-Gaza war has gone on for months, and tensions have spilled into the surrounding Middle East region.', 'The war: On Oct. 7, Hamas militants launched an unprecedented cross-border attack on Israel, killing about 1,200 people and taking civilian hostages, including from a music festival. See photos and videos of how the deadly assault unfolded. Israel declared war on Hamas in response, launching a ground invasion that fueled the biggest displacement in the region since Israel’s creation in 1948. In July 2024, Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh was killed in an attack Hamas has blamed on Israel.', 'Gaza crisis: In the Gaza Strip, Israel has waged one of this century’s most destructive wars, killing tens of thousands and plunging at least half of the population into “famine-like conditions.” For months, Israel has resisted pressure from Western allies to allow more humanitarian aid into the enclave.', 'U.S. involvement: Despite tensions between Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and some U.S. politicians, including President Biden, the United States supports Israel with weapons, funds aid packages, and has vetoed or abstained from the United Nations’ cease-fire resolutions.', 'History: The roots of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and mistrust are deep and complex, predating the establishment of the state of Israel in 1948. Read more on the history of the Gaza Strip.', '']

['This live coverage has ended. For the latest updates, please go here.', 'The crisis at the Gaza Strip’s two biggest hospitals, increasingly at the center of Israel’s military operation, escalated Monday, as Israel continued to assert that Hamas militants were taking cover in civilian buildings. Gaza’s largest hospital, al-Shifa, is surrounded by Israeli troops; at least 32 people have died in three days, a Gaza health official said. The enclave’s second-largest hospital, al-Quds in Gaza City, was encircled by Israeli forces on Monday morning and unable to evacuate its 300 remaining patients and medical employees because of bombardments and gunfire, said a spokeswoman for the Palestine Red Crescent Society, which runs the hospital. Israel said Monday that its forces killed 21 militants in the area. The Washington Post could not independently verify the claims.', '1/4', 'Follow World news', '']
['1/5', 'Follow World news', '']
